com.pb.sawdust.tabledata.read

Class TextFileTableReader<S>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pb.sawdust.tabledata.read.AbstractTableReader
      • com.pb.sawdust.tabledata.read.AbstractSubTableReader
        • com.pb.sawdust.tabledata.read.FileTableReader
          • com.pb.sawdust.tabledata.read.TextFileTableReader<S>
  • Type Parameters:
    S - The type that each row entry will be read as (usually String or String[].
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    SubTableReader, TableReader
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DelimitedTextTableReader, FixedWidthTextTableReader, WhitespaceDelimitedTextTableReader

    public abstract class TextFileTableReader<S>
extends FileTableReader
    The TextFileTableReader class is a base class for reading table data from text files. This class allows the specification of whether or not the file has a header; it is assumed that the header in a text file contains the (default) column names. If the file has no header, then default column names will be specified as: 
         
         DEFAULT_COLUMN_NAME_PREFIX + index
    where index is the (0-based) index of the column. The default is to assume that the file has a header (even if the column names are specified).

    Data types are determined through a Typer call. How deep the type checker descends into the data is configurable by the user. Using this type information, the text data is internally converted to the appropriate data types (via a (Typer).coerceToType(String,DataType) call, so user-specified types should process validly). These types The default Typer is a Typer.StandardTyper, though this can be changed by calling setTyper(Typer).

      • DEFAULT_COLUMN_NAME_PREFIX

        public static final java.lang.String DEFAULT_COLUMN_NAME_PREFIX
        The prefix for the default column names. Default names will be this string plus the (0-based) index of the column.

    • Method Detail

      • getReader

        protected abstract IterableReader<S> getReader()
        Get an iterable reader which will iterate over the rows in the table file. The actually object type which is returned by the iterator is determined by the paramatrization of this class.
        Returns:
        a reader which iterates over the rows in the table file.

      • getRowData

        protected abstract java.lang.String[] getRowData(S row)
        Get an array of row data from the input row. The input object type is determined by the paramatrization of this class.
        Parameters:
        row - The row returned from each cycle of the reader returned by getReader().
        Returns:
        an array of row data.

      • setFileHasHeader

        public void setFileHasHeader(boolean fileHasHeader)
        Set whether this reader's file has a header or not. The default value is true.
        Parameters:
        fileHasHeader - true if the file has a header, false if not.

      • setMaxTypingDepth

        public void setMaxTypingDepth(int maxDepth)
        Set the maximium depth the Typer should descend in the data to determine each column's type.
        Parameters:
        maxDepth - The type checkers maximum data depth.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if maxDepth < 1.

      • setTyper

        public void setTyper(Typer typer)
        Set the typer used to determine the data types of the text data.
        Parameters:
        typer - The typer to use to infer data types.

      • getAllColumnNames

        public java.lang.String[] getAllColumnNames()
        Description copied from class: AbstractSubTableReader
        Get all of the column names in the table (as opposed to just those for the columns being kept). User defined data types (via setColumnNames(String...) will override these values; nonetheless, this method should always return valid names for each column. Changes to the columns to keep will cause the reader to use the names returned from this method until a user overrides them; that is, these names form the default names for the table.
        Specified by:
        getAllColumnNames in class AbstractSubTableReader
        Returns:
        the names of all of the columns in the table, in the order that they occur.

      • addLineFilter

        public void addLineFilter(Filter<S> filter)
        Add a line filter to this reader. A line filter will filter lines before the data is parsed and typed.
        Parameters:
        filter - A filter which returns true if the line is to be parsed and added to the table, false otherwise.

      • clearLineFilters

        public void clearLineFilters()
        Clear any line filters held by this reader. This will not clear any row index or data filters.

      • getLineFilter

        protected Filter<S> getLineFilter()
        Get the line filter for this table reader. The returned filter will incorporate all filters added through addLineFilter(Filter<S>). In subclasses, this method should be used in combination with getReader() to form a reader which filters out lines from the file appropriately.
        Returns:
        the line filter used to filter out lines from the source table file.

      • getAllColumnTypes

        public DataType[] getAllColumnTypes()
        Description copied from class: AbstractSubTableReader
        Get all of the column types in the table (as opposed to just those for the columns being kept). User defined data types (via setColumnTypes(DataType...) will override these values; nonetheless, this method should always return valid types for each column. Changes to the columns to keep will cause the reader to use the types returned from this method until a user overrides them; that is, these types form the default types for the table.
        Specified by:
        getAllColumnTypes in class AbstractSubTableReader
        Returns:
        the types of all of the columns in the table, in the order that they occur.

      • getDataIterator

        public java.util.Iterator<java.lang.Object[]> getDataIterator()
        Description copied from class: AbstractSubTableReader
        Get an Iterator which iterates over all the rows of data in the table, in their correct order. The arrays of data should contain all of the columns (not just those from the columns to be kept) and each data element should be of the correct type corresponding to its column's data type. Data in the array corresponding to columns which are not going to be kept will be ignored, so correctly typing those elements is unnecessary. Because column types may be set externally, the typing should be performed using a combination of AbstractSubTableReader.getColumnTypes() and AbstractSubTableReader.columnsToKeep, not AbstractSubTableReader.getAllColumnTypes().
        Specified by:
        getDataIterator in class AbstractSubTableReader
        Returns:
        an iterator which cycles over all of the rows in the table.
